oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Great Smoky Mountains National Park Dedication Ceremony
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt speaking at the dedication ceremony for the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Pictured are Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, U.S. Senator Kenneth McKellar, Secretary of the Interior Harold Ickes, and Governor Prentice Cooper.

Located in East Tennessee and western North Carolina, the park was officially established in 1934 and dedicated in 1941. Men from the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) and Works Progress Administration (WPA) played a significant role in creating the park. They built hiking trails and fire watchtowers and improved infrastructure. Not all Tennesseans were happy about the park. Bit by bit the federal government purchased the land from farmers and mountaineers--often at less than acceptable prices--who were evicted.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: RG 82, Department of Conservation Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Dedications; Events; Government officials; Governors; Monuments & memorials; National parks & reserves; Presidents
